reviewText: zero stars.As a standalone B-movie, it's very mediocre, but watchable. Low expectations are richly rewarded here.If you read Wambaugh's book, you will loathe the movie because it betrays your hopes and expectations so badly. No wonder Wambaugh wanted to have his name removed from the credits. The movie tears all the flesh away from his excellent book and keeps just a few bones.If you have not read the book, but "kinda" liked the movie, read the book. You are in for a huge treat. If you read the book, but have not seen the movie, that's as far as you need go. Or read the book again.
summary: If you never read the book - three stars, if you read the book...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was fairly incredulous watching this train wreck of a comedy-drama about a group of infantile, incompetent, thoroughly undisciplined cops: legendary director Robert Aldrich ('Kiss Me Deadly,' 'The Flight of the Phoenix,' 'The Dirty Dozen,' 'The Longest Yard,' 'What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?') adapts a Joe Wambaugh novel featuring a solid roster of American character actors (James Woods, Charles Durning, Don Stroud, Vic Tayback, Louis Gossett, Jr., Randy Quaid, etc.). What could go wrong? Everything, apparently. Three quarters of 'The Choirboys' (1977)-- less a cohesive film really than a two-hour string of poorly written (and badly edited) vignettes-- is played for cheap laughs, primarily toilet humor that even the average teenager would find sophomoric, indicating that Aldrich is way out of his element here. Only the last 30 minutes gets serious, complete with cartoonish moralizing to accompany what feels like a hastily tacked-on narrative involving layers of misconduct and cover-ups, and by then you've come to dislike most of these supremely irritating public servants to a degree that you don't give a whit about their fates or feelings. A shameful waste of the talent involved. Does look nice in HD, though. 1 1/2 stars.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When "The Choirboys" was released in 1977 the elites were pretty much on board in dismissing the film as filthy, sexist, racist and homophobic.  Even the author of the source novel, Joseph Wambaugh, tried to distance himself from the film.  I was fourteen when I saw it so naturally my adolescent mindset was attuned to the film's more tawdry aspects.  I haven't seen the film in over thirty years and my reaction to it now is it was ahead of its time. Because unsavory behavior is displayed by the film's protagonists does not mean it's an unsavory work.  Have any of the film's opponents been in the company of blue collar working men and listened to how they talk and think?  . I recall a few years back the film "End of Watch" where every other word out of a police officer's mouth was a certain four letter profanity and the critics applauded the realism . The film expertly displays the day to day routine of Los Angeles' finest and how they vent after hours.  Terrific supporting cast notably Charles Durning, Tim McIntire, a young James Woods and an unshaven Burt Young.  When one considers the mainstream comedic fare of today the makers of this film come off as...choirboys.

reviewText: This is a very good movie showing what Police life was in the 70's. Wambaugh, who wrote the book was not too thrilled with it and didn't want any association with it. I would like to buy it as a DVD but the only choice was a VHS or download. The transferred copy is kind of choppy and almost appears as if copied from a VHS or television. Still glad I got it and have already watched it twice.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film, with its superlative cast and the terrific book upon which it is based, miserably failed to deliver the depth, richness and impact of that fine book.  The actors were just perfect -- Roscoe Rules and Harold Bloomguard, in particular, were portrayed stupendously -- and some of the vignettes came across properly, but in total this movie ended up being a real shame.  I read that Joseph Wambaugh wanted to have himself completely dis-associated from the film (which is one reason that the next movie made from a Wambaugh book, The Onion Field, more closely adheres to its source).Read the book, watch this film once (mainly to see how well the actors just NAILED their roles!) and then hope for a remake or, perhaps, a re-edit.
summary: Near-Complete Failure to Exploit Unbelievable Potential

reviewText: Imagine the grit of Hill Street Blues and the idiocy of Police Academy mixed mixed up with the drunken rowdiness of Porky's. Don't forget to add in a lot of unlikable cop characters who spend all their time exploiting hookers, insulting minorities, and threatening (even killing) gays. And laughing about it from beginning to end.[I'd give it zero or negative stars if that was possible.]
summary: What an awful piece of trash
Title: N/A

reviewText: Saw this movie at the flicks when first out, I liked it but it got very mixed opinions from the group I was with and the critics generally panned it. I believe it's a lot better than most give it credit for, it gives a seamy, gritty, out of the public eye (and sometimes in it) and some might say unrealistic view of the on and off duty life of a bunch of big city cops. I've seen it several times since as I have an old VHS copy of it and have enjoyed it more each time. Have to agree with Ian Holdsworth and his question of when is this going to come out on Dvd? Surely it has enough of a cult following to warrant a proper release. And the cast is excellent, a very well known at the time group of actors who all turn in very good performances. I believe Joseph Wambaugh disassociated himself with this film, so as I have not read the book I can only assume it has a fair bit of difference to it. That is possibly the reason why some do or don't enjoy it, so if you haven't read the book give it a look, or wait until hopefully the dvd comes out. Even if you have read the book just go in expecting nothing and you may also enjoy it.

reviewText: As a retired police officer who can relate to some of the antics played out in this movie. The roll call situations and the duck attack in the locker room are priceless. Some situations are surreal and in some cases did happen to officers. Great movie for the police officer type movie fans. New generations of movie goers might not understand the comedy or pranks portrayed it this almost 40 year old movie.
summary: Funny a must see for police fans.
